blog.name: gendryaonline
blog.title: a nice oak tree
blog.description: a blog dedicated to arya stark and gendry from a song of ice and fire by george r.r. martin and hbo's game of thrones

summary: Stubbornly, Arya dragged all the harder, pulling the crying girl along. Hot Pie scuttled back inside, abandoning them … but...
text: Stubbornly, Arya dragged all the harder, pulling the crying girl along. Hot Pie scuttled back inside, abandoning them … but Gendry came back, the fire shining so bright on his polished helm that the horns seemed to glow orange. He ran to them, and hoisted the crying girl up over his shoulder. “Run!”

blog.name: aqueenofmarble
blog.title: Do I Dare Disturb the Universe?

summary: I remember being pissed about Hot Pie sitting between Gendry and Arya in this scene for obvious reasons but now I‘m thinking you...
body: I remember being pissed about Hot Pie sitting between Gendry and Arya in this scene for obvious reasons but now I‘m thinking you know it makes sense because a father and mother would also want their kid to sit between them so he/she doesn‘t do anything stupid lol

summary: Interview with Ginny Di (The Singing Cosplayer)
title: Interview with Ginny Di (The Singing Cosplayer)
body:
Interview with Ginny Di (Singing Cosplayer) - This week we have a chat with Ginny Di. We talk to her about her cosplay, youtube channel, her singing talents, her love for Critical Role and more.

This week we have a chat with the singing, cosplay talents of Ginny Di.  Ginny based in Denver, the capital of Colorado, she is not only a cosplayer but she is singer, has great website with great content, youtube channel for her songs and tutorials both cosplay and photography. 

We talk to her about her cosplay, youtube channel, her singing talents, her love for Critical Role and more.

What got…

View On WordPress

tags: not giving a shit about societal standards
only who you are on the inside
summary:
arya stark positivity post
23/01
arya befriends the courtesans of braavos, and never looks down on them for their profession -...
body:
arya stark positivity post

23/01

arya befriends the courtesans of braavos, and never looks down on them for their profession - only caring that they treat her with kindness, and she does the same in return.

blog.name: she-wolf-of-highgarden

tags: A Song of Ice and Fire
doesnt seem like she has that big of an issue with them
title: Arya and Disliking Gowns
body:
(In which Arya does not talk about her dislike of dresses all that much…but like seriously am i missing some? )

“They don’t know me, Arya realized. They don’t even know I’m a girl. Small wonder; she was barefoot and dirty, her hair tangled from the long run through the castle, clad in a jerkin ripped by cat claws and brown roughspun pants hacked off above her scabby knees. You don’t wear skirts and silks when you’re catching cats. Quickly she lowered her head and dropped to one knee. Maybe they wouldn’t recognize her. If they did, she would never hear the end of it. Septa Mordane would be mortified, and Sansa would never speak to her again from the shame.” - Arya III, AGoT

“You don’t. You stink.“ Arya shoved him back against the anvil and made to run, but Gendry caught her arm. She stuck a foot between his legs and tripped him, but he yanked her down with him, and they rolled across the floor of the smithy. He was very strong, but she was quicker. Every time he tried to hold her still she wriggled free and punched him. Gendry only laughed at the blows, which made her mad. He finally caught both her wrists in one hand and started to tickle her with the other, so Arya slammed her knee between his legs, and wrenched free. Both of them were covered in dirt, and one sleeve was torn on her stupid acorn dress. "I bet I don’t look so nice now,” she shouted.” - Arya IV, ASoS

“It was even worse than before; Lady Smallwood insisted that Arya take another bath, and cut and comb her hair besides; the dress she put her in this time was sort of lilac-colored, and decorated with little baby pearls. The only good thing about it was that it was so delicate that no one could expect her to ride in it. So the next morning as they broke their fast, Lady Smallwood gave her breeches, belt, and tunic to wear, and a brown doeskin jerkin dotted with iron studs. “They were my son’s things,” she said. “He died when he was seven.” - Arya IV, ASoS

“As she sat in the common room in her stupid girl clothes, Arya remembered what Syrio Forel had told her, the trick of looking and seeing what was there. When she looked, she saw more serving wenches than any inn could want, and most of them young and comely. And come evenfall, lots of men started coming and going at the Peach.” - Arya V, ASoS

“It was quiet in the village. They had beds stuffed with straw and not too many lice, the food was plain but filling, and the air smelled of pines. All the same, Arya soon decided that she hated it. The villagers were cowards. None of them would even look at the Hound’s face, at least not for long. Some of the women tried to put her in a dress and make her do needlework, but they weren’t Lady Smallwood and she was having none of it. And there was one girl who took to following her, the village elder’s daughter. She was of an age with Arya, but just a child; she cried if she skinned a knee, and carried a stupid cloth doll with her everywhere she went.” - Arya XIII, ASoS

“I don’t wear gowns. You can’t fight in a stupid gown.“ - Arya II, AFfC

summary: I hate it when people compare Sansa Stark the future Lady of Arryn to Alysue Tangerine yes and I also hate when people act like...
body: I hate it when people compare Sansa Stark the future Lady of Arryn to Alysue Tangerine yes and I also hate when people act like Arya is copy of her useless aunt Liyen when in reality Arya loves all her siblings and parents and her Baratheon boy Gendry. Arya and Liyen aren’t comparable to each other at all. Find better role models for my girls.

blog.description: Fantasy aficionado since I read Tolkien in my teenage years. I still love Tolkien but I am also into other works. I love ASOIAF (books) and GoT (Show). I also like Brandon Sanderson, Lois McMaster Bujold, in short in my free time it's fantasy...Header by courtesy of ragekitn!

summary: Will Arya kill Da€nerys? - More tidbits from Fire and Blood
title: Will Arya kill Da€nerys? - More tidbits from Fire and Blood
body:
We are currently discussing this possible scenario over at @delulumeta and while looking at Fire and Blood I came across this story, which is a clear hint at Arya killing D and I just couldn’t resist the temptation to share this.

Moon’s murder removed the last major obstacle to the acession of Jaehaerys Targaryen to the Iron Throne, but from that day to this, debate has raged as to who was responsible for his death. No one truly believed that the woman who attempted to poison the “sinful septon” and ended by cutting his throat was acting on her won. Plainly she was but a catspaw … but whose? Did the boy king himself send her forth, or was she mayhaps an agent of his Hand, Rogar Baratheon, or his mother, the Queen Regent? Some came to believe that the woman was one of the Faceless Men, the infamous guild of sorcerer-assassins from Braavos. In support of this claim, they cited her sudden disappearance, the way she seemed to “melt into the night” after the murder, and the fact that Septon Moon’s guards could not agree on what she looked like.

Wiser man and those familiar with the ways of the Faceless Men give this theory little credence. The very clumsiness of Moon’s murder speaks against it being their work, for the Faceless Men take great care to make their killings appear as natural deaths. It is a point of pride with them, the very cornerstone of their art. Slitting a man’s throat and leaving him to stagger forth into the night screaming of murder is beneath them. Most scholars today believe that the killer was no more than a camp follower, acting at the behest of either Lord Rowan or Lord Oakheart, or mayhaps the both of them. Though neither dared desert Moon whilst he live, the alacrity with which the two lords abandoned his cause after his death suggests that their grievance had been with Maegor, not with House Targaryen…. and indeed, both men would soon return to Oldtown, penitent and obedient, to bend the knee before Prince Jaehaerys at his coronation. (Fire and Blood, The Ascencion of Jaehaerys I).

So, we have a female assassin who is a faceless man or maybe not - just like Arya is a female assassin who is not a real faceless man. She left the House of Black and White before her education was formerly over. Like Arya in the mercy chapter this female assassin kills her target by seducing him and then slitting his throat. In the show the ‘slitting a man’s throat’ has become something like a trademark for Arya. Also the woman meling into the night may evoke the “quiet as a shadow”-stealthiness that Arya already learned with Syrio Forel. It is also interesting that the word catspaw is used. It could be an allusion to Cat = Catelyn as Arya’s mother or to the dagger Arya wears in the show. We don’t know the dagger’s name in the books yet, but the show gives it as catspaw.

But why Da€nerys as the victim? Septon Moon is the last obstacle against the acession of Jaehaerys I, a king who clearly has parallels to Jon, Da€nerys is the last obstacle to Jon’s acession. It is also interesting that a Baratheon is involved, which might point towards the fact that Gendry will play a role in Arya’s decision to save Jon by killing Da€nerys. The mentioning of Jaehaerys’ mother might point towards Lyanna, Jon’s mother, who made Ned promise to protect Jon. This oath of protection will be fulfilled by the next generation, and Arya killing Da€nerys to save Jon is a possible scenario.

Last, not least, the septon who is killed here is named “Moon” and I just alert you to these:

“A trader from Qarth once told me that dragons came from the moon,” blond Doreah said as she warmed a towel over the fire. Jhiqui and Irri were of an age with Dany, Dothraki girls taken as slaves when Drogo destroyed their father’s khalasar. Doreah was older, almost twenty. Magister Illyrio had found her in a pleasure house in Lys.    (AGOT, Da€nerys III)

“My brother Rhaegar was a fierce warrior, my sun-and-stars,” she told him. “He died before I was born. Ser Jorah says that he was the last of the dragons.”          Khal Drogo looked down at her. His face was a copper mask, yet under the long black mustache, drooping beneath the weight of its gold rings, she thought she glimpsed the shadow of a smile. “Is good name, Dan Ares wife, moon of my life,” he said.  (AGOT, Da€nerys V)

These show clearly that Da€nerys is associated with the moon.

Now there is also a hint in one of Jon’s chapter which is usually thought to be a Jon€rys foreshadowing:

When they emerged north of the Wall, through a thick door made of freshly hewn green wood, the wildling princess paused for a moment to gaze out across the snow-covered field where King Stannis had won his battle. Beyond, the haunted forest waited, dark and silent. The light of the half-moon turned Val’s honey-blond hair a pale silver and left her cheeks as white as snow. She took a deep breath. “The air tastes sweet.”

“My tongue is too numb to tell. All I can taste is cold.” (ADWD, Jon  VIII)

With the passage from Fire and Blood in mind, this does even sound more ominous, but there is also this:

“Every man who walks the earth casts a shadow on the world. Some are thin and weak, others long and dark. You should look behind you, Lord Snow. The moon has kissed you and etched your shadow upon the ice twenty feet tall.” (ADWD, Jon VI)

This is usually also seen as a Jon€rys foreshadowing, but again with the killing of the Moon as told in F&B it is also rather ominous - neither shadows nor cold are a nice foreshadowing.

So, Arya will  - maybe for the sake of Gendry Baratheon, Lyanna and Jon himself, not necessarily on his order or wish -  kill Da€nerys, probably by slitting her throat with Catspaw. This will be the last obstacle against the acession of Jon as king and it will mean the death of the dragons as well.

This oath of protection will be fulfilled by the next generation, and Arya killing Da€nerys to save Jon is a possible scenario.

Last, not least, the septon who is killed here is named “Moon” and I just alert you to these:

“A trader from Qarth once told me that dragons came from the moon,” blond Doreah said as she warmed a towel over the fire. Jhiqui and Irri were of an age with Dany, Dothraki girls taken as slaves when Drogo destroyed their father’s khalasar. Doreah was older, almost twenty. Magister Illyrio had found her in a pleasure house in Lys.    (AGOT, Da€nerys III)

“My brother Rhaegar was a fierce warrior, my sun-and-stars,” she told him. “He died before I was born. Ser Jorah says that he was the last of the dragons.”          Khal Drogo looked down at her. His face was a copper mask, yet under the long black mustache, drooping beneath the weight of its gold rings, she thought she glimpsed the shadow of a smile. “Is good name, Dan Ares wife, moon of my life,” he said.  (AGOT, Da€nerys V)

These show clearly that Da€nerys is associated with the moon.

Now there is also a hint in one of Jon’s chapter which is usually thought to be a Jon€rys foreshadowing:

When they emerged north of the Wall, through a thick door made of freshly hewn green wood, the wildling princess paused for a moment to gaze out across the snow-covered field where King Stannis had won his battle. Beyond, the haunted forest waited, dark and silent. The light of the half-moon turned Val’s honey-blond hair a pale silver and left her cheeks as white as snow. She took a deep breath. “The air tastes sweet.”

“My tongue is too numb to tell. All I can taste is cold.” (ADWD, Jon  VIII)

With the passage from Fire and Blood in mind, this does even sound more ominous, but there is also this:

“Every man who walks the earth casts a shadow on the world. Some are thin and weak, others long and dark. You should look behind you, Lord Snow. The moon has kissed you and etched your shadow upon the ice twenty feet tall.” (ADWD, Jon VI)

This is usually also seen as a Jon€rys foreshadowing, but again with the killing of the Moon as told in F&B it is also rather ominous - neither shadows nor cold are a nice foreshadowing.

So, Arya will  - maybe for the sake of Gendry Baratheon, Lyanna and Jon himself, not necessarily on his order or wish -  kill Da€nerys, probably by slitting her throat with Catspaw. This will be the last obstacle against the acession of Jon as king and it will mean the death of the dragons as well.

trail.content_raw:
We are currently discussing this possible scenario over at @delulumeta and while looking at Fire and Blood I came across this story, which is a clear hint at Arya killing D and I just couldn’t resist the temptation to share this.

Moon’s murder removed the last major obstacle to the acession of Jaehaerys Targaryen to the Iron Throne, but from that day to this, debate has raged as to who was responsible for his death. No one truly believed that the woman who attempted to poison the “sinful septon” and ended by cutting his throat was acting on her won. Plainly she was but a catspaw … but whose? Did the boy king himself send her forth, or was she mayhaps an agent of his Hand, Rogar Baratheon, or his mother, the Queen Regent? Some came to believe that the woman was one of the Faceless Men, the infamous guild of sorcerer-assassins from Braavos. In support of this claim, they cited her sudden disappearance, the way she seemed to “melt into the night” after the murder, and the fact that Septon Moon’s guards could not agree on what she looked like.

Wiser man and those familiar with the ways of the Faceless Men give this theory little credence. The very clumsiness of Moon’s murder speaks against it being their work, for the Faceless Men take great care to make their killings appear as natural deaths. It is a point of pride with them, the very cornerstone of their art. Slitting a man’s throat and leaving him to stagger forth into the night screaming of murder is beneath them. Most scholars today believe that the killer was no more than a camp follower, acting at the behest of either Lord Rowan or Lord Oakheart, or mayhaps the both of them. Though neither dared desert Moon whilst he live, the alacrity with which the two lords abandoned his cause after his death suggests that their grievance had been with Maegor, not with House Targaryen…. and indeed, both men would soon return to Oldtown, penitent and obedient, to bend the knee before Prince Jaehaerys at his coronation. (Fire and Blood, The Ascencion of Jaehaerys I).

So, we have a female assassin who is a faceless man or maybe not - just like Arya is a female assassin who is not a real faceless man. She left the House of Black and White before her education was formerly over. Like Arya in the mercy chapter this female assassin kills her target by seducing him and then slitting his throat. In the show the ‘slitting a man’s throat’ has become something like a trademark for Arya. Also the woman meling into the night may evoke the “quiet as a shadow”-stealthiness that Arya already learned with Syrio Forel. It is also interesting that the word catspaw is used. It could be an allusion to Cat = Catelyn as Arya’s mother or to the dagger Arya wears in the show. We don’t know the dagger’s name in the books yet, but the show gives it as catspaw.

But why Da€nerys as the victim? Septon Moon is the last obstacle against the acession of Jaehaerys I, a king who clearly has parallels to Jon, Da€nerys is the last obstacle to Jon’s acession. It is also interesting that a Baratheon is involved, which might point towards the fact that Gendry will play a role in Arya’s decision to save Jon by killing Da€nerys. The mentioning of Jaehaerys’ mother might point towards Lyanna, Jon’s mother, who made Ned promise to protect Jon. This oath of protection will be fulfilled by the next generation, and Arya killing Da€nerys to save Jon is a possible scenario.

Last, not least, the septon who is killed here is named “Moon” and I just alert you to these:

“A trader from Qarth once told me that dragons came from the moon,” blond Doreah said as she warmed a towel over the fire. Jhiqui and Irri were of an age with Dany, Dothraki girls taken as slaves when Drogo destroyed their father’s khalasar. Doreah was older, almost twenty. Magister Illyrio had found her in a pleasure house in Lys.    (AGOT, Da€nerys III)

“My brother Rhaegar was a fierce warrior, my sun-and-stars,” she told him. “He died before I was born. Ser Jorah says that he was the last of the dragons.”          Khal Drogo looked down at her. His face was a copper mask, yet under the long black mustache, drooping beneath the weight of its gold rings, she thought she glimpsed the shadow of a smile. “Is good name, Dan Ares wife, moon of my life,” he said.  (AGOT, Da€nerys V)

These show clearly that Da€nerys is associated with the moon.

Now there is also a hint in one of Jon’s chapter which is usually thought to be a Jon€rys foreshadowing:

When they emerged north of the Wall, through a thick door made of freshly hewn green wood, the wildling princess paused for a moment to gaze out across the snow-covered field where King Stannis had won his battle. Beyond, the haunted forest waited, dark and silent. The light of the half-moon turned Val’s honey-blond hair a pale silver and left her cheeks as white as snow. She took a deep breath. “The air tastes sweet.”

“My tongue is too numb to tell. All I can taste is cold.” (ADWD, Jon  VIII)

With the passage from Fire and Blood in mind, this does even sound more ominous, but there is also this:

“Every man who walks the earth casts a shadow on the world. Some are thin and weak, others long and dark. You should look behind you, Lord Snow. The moon has kissed you and etched your shadow upon the ice twenty feet tall.” (ADWD, Jon VI)

This is usually also seen as a Jon€rys foreshadowing, but again with the killing of the Moon as told in F&B it is also rather ominous - neither shadows nor cold are a nice foreshadowing.

So, Arya will  - maybe for the sake of Gendry Baratheon, Lyanna and Jon himself, not necessarily on his order or wish -  kill Da€nerys, probably by slitting her throat with Catspaw. This will be the last obstacle against the acession of Jon as king and it will mean the death of the dragons as well.

summary: *shouts into the tumblr void* ANYONE ELSE love both Sansa and Danaerys and just wants them alive? Like I appreciate their...
body: *shouts into the tumblr void* ANYONE ELSE love both Sansa and Danaerys and just wants them alive? Like I appreciate their different faults and qualities and I love them both because they represent different types of girl power and no I don’t expect them to be bffs and say fuck you to the men and rule as badass business partners (although please someone write this please). But I want Danaerys to have the satisfying character ark she deserves and I want the starks to be happy and for people to stop the nonsense about them betraying eachother. They are a PACK, JON included. Basically I’m a lone raft of love floating around wanting positive discussion about girl power in GOT with no ship wars so if u want to climb aboard lemme know
